page.title: 03English China Clays Ltd.
page.content: The first man to find deposits of china clay in Britain was William Cookworthy, who discovered small amounts near to St. Austell in 1748. Many famous potters took leases on pits to have ready access to supplies. By the 1870's there were about 120 separate pits. Following the mergers of 1919, ECC was formed and in 1932 a further merger produced the present company: English Clays Lovering Pochin & Co. Ltd. (known simply as ECLP). In 1956 the company was divided into its present trading divisions: Quarries, Clay, Transport & Services, Building and Leisure. In 1974 ECC entered the oil industry through its interests in International Drilling Fluids. The China Clay industry is by far the most dominating aspect of this area of Cornwall affecting local employment as well as the environment. (Mike Yates)
